ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about appreciating non-traditional art like minimalism, modernism, and dadaism and how they can actually be quite interesting despite having no inherent meaning. I also gained lots of insight into what being bored even means and the value that boredom can have.

This course successfully set my standard for the English department at Yale. Professor McGowan expanded my definition of otherwise "boring" (ironic) terms, and developed my taste in art/literature. I feel much more capable of understanding art criticism and evaluating media, which is a complete switch from my first day of class. I distinctly remember walking in and feeling overwhelmed and incapable of speaking in any discussions on readings, but come the last few weeks, I became more confident and able to express myself within our small group.
I feel like I really improved my writing skills in this course, and I really enjoyed learning about all the different art history aspects as well.
Gained greater understanding of modern art, honed writing skills

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: From my experience, the title of the course very much attracted stem students into the class with no one trying to show off vocabulary or knowledge, creating a much more positive experience than many English classes my friends are in. The only weakness is the readings can be very hard to understand until the discussion and listening to others interpret what is written. As a result, sometimes discussions can be slow. Maybe some guidelines or questions to think about before reading a piece could be helpful to have and help the students try and understand what to be looking for in the texts.

Strengths were the professor, the small setting (being that there were only seven of us), the trips to view art, and the essays:
Professor McGowan is brilliant, enough said on that part. 
I appreciated the fact that there wasn't a distressing amount of people stuffed into a classroom, it allowed me to relax.
Field trips are great for bonding and enabled me to connect the theories reviewed in-class onto real works in my hands.
The essays taught me what was expected on a university-level, I had never practiced or been as serious about writing as I had ever been this first semester.

The major weakness was the reading, there were times where I could not even think to finish reading 30 pages worth of a PDF in two nights.

I really enjoyed the content in this course and I feel like the workload and homework was very reasonable and appropriate. I wish the readings were a bit simpler to understand, but the discussion of the readings during the class made up for it.
Strengths: readings and discussions were interesting and engaging

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, a thousand times over. Especially for students even slightly interested in art history, or those deeply entrenched in STEM. This course is a one-way ticket to a fine brand of intellectualism that I will value for a long time.
Yes, especially if they have an interest in art. I think there is a lot to learn in this class and I found it very interesting.
This class is great for those who want to understand modern art.

extras.title: ENGL 114 23 - Why Is Art so Boring?
